description:
Mike Beech is a director, cinematographer, editor, camera operator, drone pilot, and colourist. He has worked in a wide variety of genres including documentary, high-end TVCs, fashion, music videos, broadcast television, travel, corporate and charity projects. He is a Red camera owner and can shoot projects in resolutions up to 5k.

Mike has always had a deep passion for cinema and a love of visual art. From the first photo he took as a child on a homemade pinhole camera to shooting a feature-length documentary on a Red, he has always found inspiration in images.

His filmmaking career has allowed him to work on projects in over 25 countries globally but the majority of his work takes place in the Middle East and Seoul, South Korea.

description:
Cinematography holds a significant place in my journey, tracing back to 1995 when I embarked on my path as a videographer in my home country, Albania. Born as the son of Ibrahim Berdaku, a renowned writer and director in Albania, my upbringing was steeped in the artistry of filmmaking.

My exposure to my father’s world ignited a lifelong passion for the cinematic arts. With a rich tapestry of more than two decades in international video production, I take immense pride in my role as a catalyst for amplifying the reach of the brands I’ve collaborated with, resulting in audiences that have expanded into the millions.

Serving as the Head of Production at Ajvideo Productions Inc., I have orchestrated a diverse array of projects, spanning from grand-scale affairs like NYC Media, Mediakite, Thom Browne, Prada, Calvin Klein, Ferrari, Sothebys, Phillips, Miu Miu, Proenza, Philipp Plein, Gabriella Hearst, SKY TG24, RAI, Mediaset, and LA7, to corporate gatherings. My innate ability to anticipate and encapsulate fleeting, enchanting moments, all while maintaining an unobtrusive presence, sets me apart.

Moreover, I possess the unique gift of being trilingual, proficient in English, Italian, and Albanian, which further enriches my ability to connect with and understand diverse cultures and audiences. I am confident that my professional prowess behind the camera, coupled with my extensive experience and unwavering dedication to client satisfaction, renders me an invaluable asset to your esteemed production crew.

We are an award winning production, post production and animation studio with over 23 years of crafted storytelling 
to our name.

We create bespoke, quality content for broadcast, corporate and commercial distribution nationally and internationally. 
Our expertise lie in high end communications which exceed expectations and elevate understanding. 

We provide a seamless end to end production service. From concept briefing to production & post-production, artwork origination and animation to final delivery spread over three floors but under one roof.   

Design for Life have and continue to work with Ireland’s and the world’s leading broadcast professionals and corporate clients for whom we produce bespoke film and animated content.

projectDigests.title: The Conversation
projectDigests.description:
The Conversation is a bespoke drama-education short film created for Ireland's National utilities company; Irish Water. This short film is used as part of their on-boarding & training process to facilitate a discussion around data & identity theft and the importance of information security within the company.

The full Drama film is 12 minutes long and takes place on a moving train. The majority of the filming was completed in a single six hour day by our in-house production team.

All post-production work, including editing, VFX, sound design & colour correction was completed by Design for Life.

As a filmmaker, Scott’s independent films — including Someplace in Time, Goldfish, and others — have been recognized in over 70 festivals, museums, and exhibitions worldwide, including the 29th Raindance Film Festival, Animist Tallinn, NYC Indie Shorts Awards, Motionographer, the Museum of Fine Arts Boston, and the Kurt Vonnegut Museum and Library.

projectDigests.title: Someplace in Time
projectDigests.description:
Late at night, Billy Pilgrim finds himself marooned within his own memories.  While watching old films, he views his world in reverse, as well as the universe defying logic he attaches to it.    

Illustrating a passage from Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse-five, Someplace in Time looks through charcoal, watercolor, collage, and film to capture the mind of a man reliving his past.

Directed and animated by - Scott Palazzo
Original Score by - HOWND
Narration by - Steve Lefever

description: Rebeca Centeno is an award-winning documentary filmmaker and media professional. Her work has appeared in numerous outlets including Democracy Now!, Teen Vogue, Condé Nast (and numerous other Condé Nast brands), Truthout, ZORA, NowThis, The Washington Post, and act.tv. Her film EARTH SPEAKS was selected for The Red Nation, Santa Fe, and San Pedro International festivals and received an award at the Cinema Verde Festival in 2016. She was awarded a New York City Council Citation of Honor for her work on the LGBTQ New Americans: Oral History Project with Brooklyn Community Pride Center and Immigration Equality in 2016. She received a BFA degree from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts and an MFA degree from the Integrated Media Arts (IMA) Program at Hunter College.

projectDigests.title: LGBTQ New Americans Oral History Project | 2018 Highlight Reel
projectDigests.description: The “LGBTQ New Americans” project is designed to document and share the stories and experiences of LGBTQ immigrants, refugees and asylum seekers living in Brooklyn and New York. Since inception, immigrants have shaped our city and nation. In recent decades, we have seen an increase in immigrants and refugees who identify as LGBTQ, and their unique life stories are being woven into the fabric of our city and country. Given the tension and heated rhetoric surrounding current debates on immigration issues, it is crucial to provide a genuine platform for individuals to tell their stories and help people understand the human beings behind these complex and often abstract policy issues.

projectDigests.title: Earth Speaks
projectDigests.description: Native Americans speak about the Earth as our Mother and the impacts of oil and gas drilling on tribal lands in the United States, particularly on The Blackfeet Nation in North Central Montana. Outside entities target territories where unemployment hovers at 70%, promising wealth and prosperity, and offering little in return. The exploitation of people, land, and resources is not new to the Native

projectDigests.title: Mapfihwa GoFundMe - Help Us Water Our Dream
projectDigests.description: Mapfihwa is a community and safe space for women that is reviving Indigenous agricultural practices combined with permaculture techniques. Mapfihwa is a word in the Zimbabwean Shona language that refers to stones that are used to support the pot whilst cooking using firewood, as traditionally done in many African societies. Just like the stones that support the pot, Mapfihwa is a community where women converge to work.

projectDigests.title: Why We Kill So Many Houseplants, But Spend Billions On Them Anyway
projectDigests.description: Houseplants are all the rage. But as Americans buy more plants, and producers scale up to meet demand, more plants are dying. About 40% of plants perish in the supply chain, and another 35% die in customers' homes. So what are plant producers and influencers doing about it? We went to one of America's largest plant farms to find out.

projectDigests.title: “Nunca me dijeron que iba a recibir insultos y amenazas personales”: el precio de una visa H-2A en Texas
projectDigests.description: Decenas de trabajadores en una planta procesadora de papas sufren abusos y resisten en silencio. No quieren perder sus empleos. Muchos no saben que están siendo víctimas. Creen que si denuncian ellos serán los castigados y no sus explotadores.

projectDigests.title: Extreme violence is driving many Salvadoran girls to kill themselves or flee
projectDigests.description: María, from El Salvador, tried to kill herself when she was 15 years old. In the country with the most femicides in the most violent region in the world, where brutality has been instigated by gangs and naturalized by society and the State, the girls who take their own lives are smaller and smaller. Nobody talks about it.

description:
As a seasoned professional in the field of film and television production, I bring over 8 years of experience to the role of Director of Photography and Filmmaker. Throughout my career, I have worked with a diverse range of organizations and humanitarian groups, directing, producing and supervising various media and arts projects, as well as mass information campaigns on various thematic issues. My work has been recognized for its quality and ability to effectively communicate with communities.

I have extensive experience in pre-production and production aspects of filmmaking, including director of photography and editing. I am also a skilled manager and leader, with a proven track record of successfully leading multimedia projects and teams.

I specialize in utilizing visual media as a tool for social transformation, with a focus on telling human-interest stories. I have a strong background in cinematography, photography, editing, script writing, and production management, and am proficient in using industry-standard software such as Final Cut Pro and Adobe.

I am highly accomplished in my field and have won awards for my work. My past clients include Film Aid Kenya, Tullow Oil PLC, County Government of Turkana, World Vision Kenya, NDMA, UNHCR, IOM, Windle Trust Kenya, Aga Khan University of Media and Communication, Chams Media Ltd and IRC. I am confident that my experience and skill set make me an excellent candidate for any project or company in need of a professional filmmaker and director of photography.

projectDigests.description: "Heroic Cut", a film produced by FilmAid in Kenya, is aimed at demonstrating the importance and benefits of Voluntary Medical Male Circumcision (VMMC) in non-circumcising communities, as a means of preventing HIV/AIDS and other Sexually-transmitted Infections (STIs) by up to 60 percent.

projectDigests.title: PRICE OF POWER PROMO
projectDigests.description: Geothermal energy, which is a clean low carbon energy resource, currently provides half of Kenya’s energy needs.  Its importance will keep growing as Kenya’s tries to connect 90 % of its citizens to the electric power grid. Unfortunately most geothermal fields are in National Parks and Reserves, and often endanger critically endangered bird species.  Elsewhere geothermal power plants require the displacement of local people.  The film explores the price of power, even for an energy resource that is touted as clean and carbon free.

projectDigests.title: Someplace in Time
projectDigests.description:
Late at night, Billy Pilgrim finds himself marooned within his own memories.  While watching old films, he views his world in reverse, as well as the universe defying logic he attaches to it.    

Illustrating a passage from Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse-five, Someplace in Time looks through charcoal, watercolor, collage, and film to capture the mind of a man reliving his past.

Directed and animated by - Scott Palazzo
Original Score by - HOWND
Narration by - Steve Lefever

projectDigests.title: Is Our Couchsurfing Revolution Still Alive?
projectDigests.description:
Founded in the early days of still open source internet, Couchsurfing rejected capitalist norms and promised a revolution in the way we travel and connect with others around the globe.  In 2020, in stark contrast to its long held values, the service implemented a mandatory access fee, alienating many of its users and leaving longtime Couchsurfers wondering: is our global revolution still alive?

description:
Ryan is a New York-based filmmaker with a flair for turning subtle, everyday moments into compelling stories with broad appeal, particularly through the universal language of sports.

His journey behind the camera began on the sidelines of high school football games in Texas. As he moved on to film and documentary work, Ryan developed a profound belief in the power of empathy, drawing from a tapestry of his own diverse human experiences that would inspire his approach to narratives that resonate deeply and authentically.

Educated at NYU's graduate film program, Ryan's foundation in filmmaking is robust, recognized by industry accolades such as the Best Test Commercial at YDA in Cannes for his Nike spot "Buckets". His debut transcends the arena of sports, offering a lens into the human condition and capturing the collective ethos that brands and agencies strive to embody.

With an eye for the emotive force of storytelling, Ryan’s ambition is to craft campaigns that don't just sell, but also tell a story that audiences will remember and feel a part of. His vision for the future is expansive, seeking to collaborate on projects that challenge societal norms and ignite conversations.

Brands and agencies should partner with Ryan for his fresh perspective that blends the traditional with the avant-garde, his commitment to authenticity, and his proven ability to connect with viewers on an emotional level. His work is a testament to the potential of creative advertising to not just reach an audience, but to touch it profoundly.

When not weaving narratives, Ryan is usually cooking at home in Brooklyn, or exploring the world’s coastlines with his fiancée Stephanie.

Whether you spot her in front of the camera or behind the lens, you’ll recognize this fierce female filmmaker sporting pink lipstick and an armful of camera gear!  She calls Denver, Colorado her home and her launchpad, where she springs off to adventures near and far.  Maybe you've seen Jules on CNN Airport Network waiting for a flight.  She’s also been spotted on networks like PBS, Local Now, Matador Network, Lonely Planet, USA TODAY, Viator and beyond.  Jules recently got back from a round the world storytelling adventure as Bumble’s Global Connector Bee.  Travel brands and tourism boards are big fans of Jules – her enthusiasm and joie de vivre make her vlogs a delight to watch.  Jules is also a global Manfrotto Ambassador, always up to date on the latest camera tools and trends.  She shares creative and technical tips on her website, The Video Hustle.  Jules serves on the Board of Governors for the Heartland Chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.  She is also a Travel Massive Colorado chapter leader.  In her spare time, you’ll find Jules snowboarding in Vail where she is a certified instructor.  Come along for the adventure with TravelingJules on Facebook, Instagram and on her travel vlog on YouTube.  Happy travels!

“The tree is kind of born and raised and grows up on the mountain, it comes back in the form of skis, and it skis right back through where it grew up to begin with,” Meier Skis owner Ted Eynon told Popular Mechanics.

To help Roman and Jennifer rescue more dogs like Buster, you can support Project Freedom Ride: https://thedo.do/pfrdonate.

projectDigests.title: Inside The Largest Handmade Candy Factory | MADE HERE | Popular Mechanics
projectDigests.description:
For a century, Hammond's Candies has been hand-making its world-famous confections in Denver. Clearly, there's something sweet in the water out there—so for the latest episode of the Popular Mechanics series "MADE HERE," we visited the factory where old family recipes and a love of artisanal products continue to make Hammond's a magical place.

It all began when Carl T. Hammond, Sr. dropped out of high school and got a job as an apprentice at a candy factory. After years of toiling at different factories, Hammond ventured out on his own and opened up Hammond's Candy Company in 1920.

description:
Shravan Vidyarthi is the founder of Intersect,  a global video and photo production company. We make it easy for corporations and nonprofits to tell great stories anywhere in the world.

Why “intersect?” Because we defy boundaries and love bringing ideas and people together. 

We help our clients define their creative vision, and bring it to life with seamless shoots and artful post-production.

Recently we’ve been on location in Colombia, Ethiopia, Ghana, Jamaica, Senegal and Rwanda for clients like Land O’Lakes and the MasterCard Foundation, and we are excited to see where our work takes us next.

Intersect was founded by Shravan Vidyarthi, a filmmaker and photographer based in New York and his native Nairobi, Kenya. His documentaries have screened on PBS and at MoMA, appeared in The New York Times, and won awards at international film festivals. Shravan has broad experience in the developing world, and speaks English, French, Swahili and Punjabi.

projectDigests.title: P&G Always
projectDigests.description: We were commissioned by Procter & Gamble to show how Always sanitary pads are changing the lives of young girls in Kenya. With access to affordable feminine health products, girls are able to stay in school longer. We mobilized a crew in Nairobi in less than 24 hours. Working in both English and Swahili, we produced and directed both video and stills.

projectDigests.title: CNN HEROES - Vednita Carter
projectDigests.description: The CNN Heroes series profiled Minneapolis’ Vednita Carter, who has helped more than 6,000 victims of sex trafficking. Once a former sex worker herself, Vednita has built an army of survivors who have joined her crusade to end sex trafficking. Taking an empathetic approach to a difficult subject, we worked to make the women comfortable on camera while also protecting their identities.

projectDigests.title: USAA - Gene Kranz
projectDigests.description: The USAA, a leading financial and insurance provider for the military community, wanted to show their dedication to military families. Working with VSA Partners in Chicago, Intersect profiled Gene Kranz, former NASA flight control director for Apollo 13. We shot in Houston and worked closely with NASA to get access to locations and archival footage.

projectDigests.title: Doha Debates: Painting A Brighter Future in Palestine
projectDigests.description:
Ismail Matar is a Palestinian refugee and an artist — and the streets of Gaza City are his canvas.

Born and raised in the Khan Younis refugee camp, Ismail has lived his entire life in a war zone — but he strives to bring hope and joy to his community through his artwork.

In May 2021, the Israeli military carried out 11 days of airstrikes in Gaza, killing at least 260 Palestinians, 66 of whom were children. The attacks also destroyed countless homes and buildings, and much of Ismail’s street art became rubble.

For Ismail, rebuilding Gaza City, his home, means painting new images of hope and humanity in Palestine. Today, he helps children use art to channel their feelings and process their grief and trauma so that they can build a brighter future for themselves.

“We have dreams and ambitions,” he said. “We want to live with dignity.”

projectDigests.title: 10yo Gaza
projectDigests.description:

description:

I also have conflict journalism experience having reported and produced documentaries in places like Afghanistan, Syria, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, Turkey and Southern Thailand.

I have produced numerous feature documentaries that have gone on to screen in various international film festivals. And I am an author and have written four non-fiction books to date.

description:
Marcia is a seasoned production manager and line producer who has also served as a showrunner on several productions. With extensive experience in television, film and commercial productions, she has worked in South Africa, throughout the African continent, and around the world for nearly twenty years.  
Marcia most recently managed a team from the U.S. headquarters of AirBnB in Cape Town. During the funeral of former South African President Nelson Mandela, she managed BET News’ team in three locations across the country. Marcia has also served as a content producer and researcher for History Channel’s History of Football in Africa and Making World Cup History in the lead up to the 2018 FIFA Soccer World Cup.  She lead the production team on the international feature film The Journey is the Destination and worked on Netflix’s Jadotville shot on location in Johannesburg. Prior to that, Marcia line produced For Love and Broken Bones, a made-for-TV South African film which won Best Film Award at the Portland International Film Festival.
Marcia was part of the launch team of Comedy Club: Live in Lagos which grew to become a continent-wide platform for African comedians.  With increasing responsibility from production manager, line producer and finally series producer she expanded the program working to create seasons in Mombasa and Kampala. She also production managed a season of Coke Studio East/West, a pan-African television music show broadcast to thirteen countries and translated into eight languages. Marcia led the production unit of Studio 53, a pan-African magazine show. She has worked across all television genres holding senior production and content roles in talk, drama, live TV, and reality. 
Marcia has typically overseen productions from inception to post-production and she is extremely well versed in budgeting, scheduling, day-to-day management of cast and crew, brainstorming content and post production. She has exceptional organisational, communication and management skills, and has travelled extensively for work and pleasure.
In 2018, Marcia returned to Vassar College on a full scholarship to write her thesis thereby completing her BA degree in Africana Studies. Her strong analytical and research skills as well as her life experience as a mature student helped her fulfil this long-standing goal.

description:
I was born in 1989, in a middle class family in Bangladesh. I studied computer science, before leaving my computer career to study photography at Pathshala South Asian Media Institute from 2010 to 2013, where I was also trained to produce and edit Audio-Visuals. I learnt photography from the masters like Morten Krogvold, Philip Blenkinsop, Max Pam, Asim Rafiqui and Shahidul Alam. I also worked under mentorship of Saiful Huq Omi for a year.

My works got published in National Geographic, Sky News UK, Trouw, Marie Claire Italia, Saudi Aramco World, Daily Mail UK, Sunday Times, Birding Asia, SAEVUS among others. I have also worked for The New York Times, Thomson Reuters Foundation, Save The Children, Channel 4, Human Rights Watch, Equal Rights Trust, Embassy of The Kingdom of Netherlands, European Union among others. 

Currently I’m working as a Documentary photographer/cinematographer at a agency called “Counter Foto”. I also work as a contributor at Polaris Images and Thomson Reuters Foundation.  

I’m working with Saiful Huq Omi in his mammoth documentary film project on Rohingya refugees around the world as an assistant producer and co-cinematographer.

description:
Ana Gonzalez is a producer/director & journalist with experience in more than 20 countries. She has collaborated with media outlets such as the BBC, Atlas Obscura, NatGeo, TIME, Al Jazeera, Mediaset and others. In 2021, her documentary “Flamenco Queer” was released by The New Yorker with support from the Pulitzer Center. Ana was previously a correspondent for an international press agency in Paris and Bangkok, where she helped the company set up its multimedia headquarters for Asia –a continent she went on to explore extensively during four years as a freelance filmmaker with a base in Indonesia.

 In 2020, she founded Eye Rise Films –an audiovisual production house (with headquarters in London and Barcelona) which tells stories that challenge the way we perceive the world. ERF offers production services for commercial productions, branded content, documentaries, series and others, from conception to delivery. The production company counts with an experienced crew and high-end equipment available for productions worldwide.

projectDigests.title: The Guardian of the Axolotl
projectDigests.description: In Xochimilco, Mexico, Manuel Rodriguez is on a mission to save the country’s native and endangered axolotl, a small amphibious animal that can regenerate its body parts. He shelters up to 14,000 creatures at a time at his sanctuary and also puts on a show once a year to educate children and families about the animal in his homemade axolotl costume. He credits the axolotl for helping him find a path away from drugs.

projectDigests.title: Flamenco Queer – The New Yorker
projectDigests.description: In the film “Flamenco Queer,” by Ana González and Frederick Bernas, a queer man’s lifelong passion for flamenco comes out after decades of hiding feminine impulses in a conservative society with rigid cultural traditions.  The documentary has been acquired by The New Yorker and has received support from The Pulitzer Center.

description:
My name is Luis Carballo. In 1997 I started my professional career in journalism and since then I have found nothing better to do. At that moment began an adventure that took me around the world. Thanks to my work on an international television network, I was able to cover events such as the earthquake in Haiti in 2010, the Egyptian revolution in 2011, the wars between Israel and Hamas, the visit of Pope Francis to Holy Land and the funerals of Ariel Sharon and Hugo Chavez. Afterwards, in 2015, my report in Nigeria on Boko Haram was selected for the Emmy Awards.

For years I have worked in front of the camera as a reporter, presenter and interviewer, but also a lot behind it, because I have been producing reports and documentaries on a free-lance basis for a long time.

I do all kinds of video production, journalistic or commercial, for a wide range of clients: media, institutions, NGO and companies.

Besides, I shoot and edit all my work with my own professional equipment and the know-how from two decades of experience in TV.

Restless by nature, I’ve also been a professional photographer since the 1990s. At the end of 2001 I created in Barcelona, together with the French photographer, Jean Pierre Porcher, the photo agency, Gran Angular.

I am also a drone operator. Have all the official diplomas to fly drones up to 2 kg in any European country.

projectDigests.title: 99 yr old Marietta makes tagliatelle with vegetable sauce | Pasta Grannies
projectDigests.description:
99 year old Marietta is still going strong - we first met her in Calabria 18 months ago - and we caught up with her in Rome. This is one of her regular pasta dishes which everyone can adapt and make their own. Stew onion, carrot and celery before adding about 500g of greens like chard, cabbage, dandelion, kale and so on. Add a fresh red chilli if you like.  Pour over some tomato passata, season with salt and leave to simmer for 20 minutes. 
For her pasta, Marietta uses semola rimacinata/durum wheat flour and water. Allow 300g flour, and 145g of water with a pinch of salt.

projectDigests.title: Parole (s) de Gilet Jaune DOCUMENTAIRE
projectDigests.description:
Un an. On a partagé. On a discuté, on a trouvé la fraternité, on a vécu ensemble. On s’est fait gazer, matraquer, nasser. Ensemble. Vous, les « Gilets Jaunes », et nous, les journalistes. En principe, un des premiers devoirs d’un journaliste, c’est d’être « objective », et de garder la distance. On ne peut pas. On ne peut pas garder la distance, parce-que la cause des « Gilets Jaunes » - c’est la nôtre, c’est juste, c’est pour avancer la société. On ne peut pas rester indiffèrent. Parce-que la réalité s’impose : Nous sommes obligés de vivre avec un gouvernement qui est en train de détruire toutes les réussites qui sont les résultats d’un combat qui a duré des décennies et même plus. Pour l’instant.

Au début c’était un phénomène sociologique, politique, un phénomène étonnant. « Çà vas se passer », on a dit. Non. Ça ne va pas se passer. C’est historique. Vous êtes encore là, nous sommes encore là. On s’intéresse. Let mots, c’est dit. On vous invite, alors, de regarder le film qu’on a réalisé depuis le début du mouvement en novembre 2018. En espérant qu’il y aura une deuxième partie.

projectDigests.title: How FIFA world Cup 2014,2018, UEFA Champions Leagues Match balls made in Sialkot
projectDigests.description:
We avail the opportunity to cover the process “ How FIFA world Cup 2014,2018, UEFA Champions Leagues Match balls made in Sialkot” and Interview the Mr. Masood Akthar Khawaja, Chairman of the World’s largest Soccer balls manufacturing unit, where almost 1.3 billion balls made every year in a single factory in Pakistan. 

Background:
Nearly 70% of the world's soccer balls are made in the city of Sialkot, Pakistan. Home to nearly 1,000 soccer ball factories, and employing nearly 60,000 people, this city is the epicenter for the world's most popular sport, enjoyed by over 4 billion people.
Here's what it's like inside one of those factories, where balls are largely still made by hand.

description:
I'm a freelance filmmaker and video journalist focused primarily on documentary projects. I'm currently picking up short-term gigs as a Freelance Producer, Editor, or Videographer while I work on a part-time commissioned short documentary based out of Nebraska.

I most recently finished working on a project with production company Meerkat Media on a commission from Sesame Street in Communities. The project entails documentary-style educational videos about how to talk to kids about race and racism through observing real families in conversation with their children.

Prior to delving into full-time freelance life, I worked as an Associate Producer on seven feature-length historic documentaries produced by CNN Specials as well as an observational film produced by HBO Max/CNN Films.

Independently, with my production partner Sana A. Malik, I produced, shot, and edited the student BAFTA-award winning documentary, Guanajuato Norte. The film follows a migrant farmworker in Connecticut and his sacrifice of being away from his family to provide a better life for his children. The film went on to screen multiple film festivals and was acquired by The New Yorker’s Documentary Channel.

I also co-directed the short film, Chief Standing Bear's Journey to Statuary Hall, for the Nebraska Commission on Indian Affairs with Judi gaiashkibos (co-director and EP.) Together, we made a film to be used as an educational resource, following the historical story of Ponca Chief Standing Bear and the modern-day journey of building a statue of his likeness to stand in the U.S. Capitol.

In addition to working as a Director/Producer on commissioned short films and personal projects, I love helping established Director’s visions come to life as an Associate Producer, Editor, or Second Camera. I’m easily curious but particularly drawn toward stories about migration, family, social justice, and the meaning of home.

description:
How many times have your eyes sparkled with delight?

Diogo Pessoa de Andrade is a filmmaker, director, and cinematographer with over twenty years of expertise in the audiovisual and digital media industries. Over the years, he has honed his skills in creating content for diverse audiences across various platforms, ranging from creative media and entertainment to informative content, advertising, awareness campaigns, and educational materials. Diogo has collaborated with numerous local and international brands, agencies, production companies, public and private institutions, as well as non-governmental organizations.

Diogo's passion for the visual arts began in his adolescence with painting, leading him to pursue a degree in mechanical engineering due to family expectations. However, after completing his university studies and internship as a marine machinery engineer, he decided to shift his professional focus towards multimedia. He participated in numerous funded courses in multimedia, crossmedia and transmedia storytelling, sound, photography, and video, ultimately leading him to work as a multimedia technician developing interactive audiovisual content. 

In 2005, Diogo traveled to Barcelona to study documentary filmmaking, and upon returning to Lisbon, he worked in advertising as a developer and creator of interactive audiovisual content. In 2009 he enrolled in a master's degree program in digital cinema. In 2010, after being laid off from his advertising job during the economic crisis that started in 2008,  he subsequently became a self-employed audiovisual creator, dedicating himself 100% to video production and creation.

As a content creator, Diogo produces narratives, documentaries, music videos, video content for advertising and marketing campaigns, corporate videos, live events, staff videos and internal communication, promotional videos and news He is also a certified trainer and has provided training and consulting services in film and audiovisual creation since 2006.

Based in Lisbon, Portugal, Diogo is available for both domestic and international video production projects. He is equipped to handle various types of productions, with access to state-of-the-art digital cinema and audio equipment and established connections with local video production companies and studios, as well as rental companies and industry professionals. Having worked in several countries in Europe, Africa and Asia, Diogo brings a global perspective to his work and is comfortable working in diverse cultural contexts.

Diogo can help you accomplish your objectives whether you're a brand looking for a new approach to your next video campaign or a production business searching for a trustworthy partner. If you have any questions regarding a brand-new concept for your upcoming video production or a potential business partnership, please contact Diogo.

projectDigests.title: KAICIID International Fellows Programme
projectDigests.description:
The KAICIID International Fellows Programme is a one-year learning and training programme that empowers institutions that train future religious leaders by providing capacity-building to select teachers. The aim is to facilitate dialogue encounters by giving these teachers and practitioners the tools, experience, networking opportunities and knowledge to pursue interreligious dialogue (IRD) projects and further prepare their own students to become facilitators and leaders in IRD. 

From 21 to 24 February 2022, the 2020 KAICIID Fellows Programme took place in Lisbon, Portugal. 61 religious leaders, dialogue practitioners and educators from around the world graduated from the 2020 KAICIID Fellows Programme. They are now ready to implement more small scale initiatives to promote dialogue in their own communities!

description:
A.J. Olstad’s passion for sound began with his love for films. He often wondered how the sounds were made and wanted to recreate them. His curiosity drove him to enroll at Columbia College Chicago, where he worked as a sound designer for various films -- including several that won in the Chicago International Film Festival and other independent festivals. He also worked on numerous projects as a location sound recorder. His talents took him to Sri Lanka, Miami, and Wyoming, where he was exposed to incredible learning experiences in sound.
After graduating with a Bachelor of Arts in Audio for Visual Arts in 2015,  A.J. landed an internship at NoiseFloor Ltd., where he quickly became acclimated to the professional clientele and workflow. His dedication and passion for the business earned him a promotion as a Sound Editor, which put him on larger scale projects like web & TV spots for OtterBox, Honda, and Special Olympics, the short TV show The Jamz, and the video game Injustice 2. His location audio career has also grown as he’s worked on projects such as Restore Hair Restoration with Brian Urlacher, Family Travels with Colleen Kelly and the United States Marine drum and bugle corps. He’s even had the opportunity to record Wayne Brady for a SEG TV & Radio spot.
Though his career is just beginning, A.J. has already traveled to New York, London, Maryland, and San Francisco as a location sound recorder and worked on multiple large scale projects in he River North studios. He takes each day as a learning opportunity and plans on seeing more success at NoiseFloor.

description:
I am a bilingual French English journalist who grew up in the Alps. I studied International Journalism at Cardiff University, where I graduated with a distinction.

My main area of interest lies in geopolitics and human rights. I  investigated the effects of religious nationalism in Armenia, questioning democratic processes and the roles played by the church in society and politics.

I have shot and edited stories on refugees from Calais to Cardiff, but also covered cultural topics from sneaker trends to the art of graffiti. 

Former BMX-race athlete, I am a sport-addicted which led me to cover women and girls in sport and other punchy stories including on the business of Mixed Martial Arts. 

By nature, I am curious and adventurous, I like to observe new cultures and to learn from people. Having travelled in many countries, I have a multicultural and open-minded perspective of the world: I understand four languages. For me, journalism is a field of exploration and encounters. I like to listen, to feel, to perceive, to shoot pictures and to transcribe the experience by sharing these impressions through reporting.

I am currently working for France24  for the French and the English channels. My reports have been published by InsideOver, Voice Of America, and Worldcrunch.  I also used to work for several magazines and newspaper in France including L’Équipe, Courrier International and Le Dauphiné Libéré. I also used to be a reporter for the Paris-based Institute Open Diplomacy.

As a young woman, I want to prove to my generation why journalism matters. I am convinced that understanding our environment requires a thorough study of the world. I believe journalism is a means of involvement and engagement. I want to share with society my passion for international news, and to convince others of its importance.
Determination, tenacity and optimism drive my everyday life!

projectDigests.title: Dolphins killed in France: Fishermen and NGOs clash over accidental catches • FRANCE 24 English
projectDigests.description: Since the beginning of the year, more than 400 #dolphins have been found dead on the beaches of #France's west coast. This disturbing phenomenon is due to accidental catches by non-selective fishing gear. About 200,000 dolphins live in the Bay of Biscay, but rights groups fear the species will be driven to the brink of extinction. The European Commission already put France on notice in 2020 for its ineffectiveness in saving dolphins, an animal essential to the ecosystem and one that's strictly protected under European and French law. The government has now implemented an action plan. But will it be effective? FRANCE 24's Jade Lévin report.

projectDigests.title: COP26-Environnement : à la chasse aux pollueurs des décharges sauvages
projectDigests.description: Avant le début de la COP26 à Glasgow dimanche 31 octobre, focus sur un désastre environnemental : les décharges sauvages. Selon l'association WWF, en France, au moins 80 000 tonnes de déchets sont déposés illégalement dans la nature chaque année. Ces décharges sauvages nuisent à la biodiversité et participent au réchauffement climatique par l'émission de gaz à effet de serre. Le collectif "La Brigade écologiste" lutte pour retrouver les pollueurs, passibles de 75 000 euros d'amende et deux ans de prison.

projectDigests.title: Caldor Fire brings chaos to lake Tahoe resort
projectDigests.description: Flames race across treetops and through drought-stricken #vegetation as firefighters scramble to keep a growing California wildfire from reaching a resort city at the southern tip of Lake Tahoe.

description:
Charles is an East Coast based photographer and cinematographer whose passion for capturing the beauty in the brutal has taken him globally, from the continental United States to the Far East. Eating and Working and  Eating and Working is a feature-length documentary film that follows seven people working in food from the beginning to the end of their work day. Along the way, participants discuss the joys and frustrations of working, the skills utilized in their labor, and the impacts of sexism, racism, and classism on their work environments. projectDigests.title: Wild Human (documentary trailer)
projectDigests.description:
Wild Human, the ninth feature-length documentary film from Pittsburgh filmmaker/artist/musician David Bernabo, investigates how humanity has replaced wilderness with representations of wilderness.

From maps to national parks to Sea World to nature photographs, humanity’s designs for the world alter the context in which wilderness exists. The results can be harmless (a floral print dress), catastrophic (nuclear bombs), noble (maintaining national parks), or complicated (upsetting natural cycles of life and death while managing fires in Aspen). Falling somewhere between documentary, personal research project, podcast, and performance video, Wild Human uses unorthodox storytelling to indulge in philosophical questions, quirky history, and a bit of doomsaying in analyzing humanity’s loss of wilderness and its piecemeal reconstruction.

A theme of iterative destruction, masking, and alteration of “the wild” arises when exploring topics such as hidden sites on Google Maps, virtual reality, ghost towns, and systems that damage or re-contextualize the natural world like war and the stock market. A diverse pool of media is utilized from Youtube fail videos to archival footage to beautiful sequences filmed during road trips through Colorado, Utah, and Arizona.

description:
Hello! My name is Nacho Corbella and storytelling is my passion. I love shaping a story, shooting and been in the field, interviewing, and everything else content gathering entails. There's something athletic in the act. You put your whole body and mind into it. It's exhausting but tremendously fulfilling. 

I enjoy enormously assembling the puzzle of what a multimedia story is. Reviewing and selecting material, deciding which asset is best to convey what the story portrays. It's like writing, but far better. You can have the most beautiful images and incredible bits of audio, but if you don't know how to order them and ultimately make sense of them for the viewer, it's useless. It's like loose words on a piece of paper. That's what I love about editing: you're creating a language. It's a full on mind game.

Multimedia is the type of work that I love engaging with and doing, but also the type of work that I think is meaningful and can promote change. I firmly believe is a medium that can reach people and spur them to understand issues fully and, consequently help bring change, especially when done with dedication and quality.

description:
After graduating from film school and before immersing myself in the documentary world, I began working as a correspondent for Associated Press Television at the age of 24. That journey included nearly 13 years of work and training in breaking news. I had the opportunity to cover stories in extraordinary places and meet fascinating people.

The genesis of my career was influenced by a family connection to journalism - I grew up hearing stories from my uncle Hermes, a war correspondent for NBC. He covered events such as the Gulf War, Sarajevo, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Cuba. His experiences inspired me to embark on my own travels and stories, much like he did.

As time went on, I gained more experience and realized that my destiny was not to cover wars and conflicts. My projects and concerns have always been related to social awareness, with a focus on making a positive impact on the audience. I began to search for the best way to use my passion and creativity to make films that truly make a difference. 

In 2014, the combination of my Academy training in documentary and my curiosity for new ways of telling stories pulled me away from the breaking news cycle. I then adapted my journalism experience into a modern storytelling style that takes advantage of the often unique opportunities we have to get a shot that dramatically moves the story forward. As a documentary director and DOP, I'm constantly looking for artistic balance and social impact in my stories. 

Based in Buenos Aires, Argentina, my projects demonstrate a deep concern and commitment to social issues and justice. Today I direct documentaries with a deeply personal approach and help others raise their voices. Combining teamwork and expertise, I work comfortable into sensitive stories which require strong visuals with limited budget and timing.

projectDigests.title: Doha Debates: Painting A Brighter Future in Palestine
projectDigests.description:
Ismail Matar is a Palestinian refugee and an artist — and the streets of Gaza City are his canvas.

Born and raised in the Khan Younis refugee camp, Ismail has lived his entire life in a war zone — but he strives to bring hope and joy to his community through his artwork.

In May 2021, the Israeli military carried out 11 days of airstrikes in Gaza, killing at least 260 Palestinians, 66 of whom were children. The attacks also destroyed countless homes and buildings, and much of Ismail’s street art became rubble.

For Ismail, rebuilding Gaza City, his home, means painting new images of hope and humanity in Palestine. Today, he helps children use art to channel their feelings and process their grief and trauma so that they can build a brighter future for themselves.

“We have dreams and ambitions,” he said. “We want to live with dignity.”

projectDigests.title: Peace. Friendship. An occupation.
projectDigests.description: In 1941, shortly after the attack of Nazi Germany on the USSR, Stalin decided to send troops to Iran. The Soviet dictator acted in concert with Great Britain, which also announced its military presence in Iran. The allied powers explained these actions by the fact that they want to minimize Hitler's influence in this part of Asia. They promised that as soon as Nazi Germany was defeated, the troops would leave Iran. But for the USSR, this became a convenient pretext for putting pressure on its southern neighbor. At the end of World War II, Stalin wanted to get oil concessions in Iran. When the country's leadership refused to do so, he began to blackmail the Iranian government with the creation of an independent Azerbaijani state in northern Iran. The confrontation between the USSR and Iran became the first chapter in the long history of international conflicts in which the leading world powers found themselves on opposite sides.

description:
Austin Meyer is a documentary filmmaker and photographer based in Oakland, CA. He is a National Geographic Explorer and his work has been featured by HBO, Hulu, Apple TV, National Geographic, The New York Times, Washington Post, The Atlantic, PBS NewsHour, and Al Jazeera among others.

Meyer graduated from Stanford University with a B.A. degree in creative writing and an M.A. degree in journalism. After graduation, he was selected as the winner of the New York Times’ International Reporting Trip with Nicholas Kristof competition, for which he reported for the New York Times in Baltimore, India, and Nepal.

Meyer has worked as a videographer at the Los Angeles Times and was awarded an IDEO storytelling fellowship, during which he reported for Slate on the social and environmental impacts of hydropower dams along the Mekong River in Southeast Asia. In 2018 Meyer was awarded a National Geographic Explorer grant to create a documentary film on maternal healthcare in Zambia. His documentaries have screened at the American Documentary, Mill Valley, & Milwaukee Film Festivals, as well as in the National Geographic Short Film Showcase and Atlantic Selects series.

Meyer’s purpose as a documentarian is to tell stories that change the way people walk through the world by inspiring empathy, curiosity, and wonder. He is passionate about telling vulnerable and intimate stories that are emotionally moving, break down stereotypes, and compel people to take action in order to make our world a better place.

www.austinmeyerfilms.com
@austinmeyerfilms on social media

description:
Ana Gonzalez is a producer/director & journalist with experience in more than 20 countries. She has collaborated with media outlets such as the BBC, Atlas Obscura, NatGeo, TIME, Al Jazeera, Mediaset and others. In 2021, her documentary “Flamenco Queer” was released by The New Yorker with support from the Pulitzer Center. Ana was previously a correspondent for an international press agency in Paris and Bangkok, where she helped the company set up its multimedia headquarters for Asia –a continent she went on to explore extensively during four years as a freelance filmmaker with a base in Indonesia.

 In 2020, she founded Eye Rise Films –an audiovisual production house (with headquarters in London and Barcelona) which tells stories that challenge the way we perceive the world. ERF offers production services for commercial productions, branded content, documentaries, series and others, from conception to delivery. The production company counts with an experienced crew and high-end equipment available for productions worldwide.

projectDigests.title: The Guardian of the Axolotl
projectDigests.description: In Xochimilco, Mexico, Manuel Rodriguez is on a mission to save the country’s native and endangered axolotl, a small amphibious animal that can regenerate its body parts. He shelters up to 14,000 creatures at a time at his sanctuary and also puts on a show once a year to educate children and families about the animal in his homemade axolotl costume. He credits the axolotl for helping him find a path away from drugs.

projectDigests.title: Flamenco Queer – The New Yorker
projectDigests.description: In the film “Flamenco Queer,” by Ana González and Frederick Bernas, a queer man’s lifelong passion for flamenco comes out after decades of hiding feminine impulses in a conservative society with rigid cultural traditions.  The documentary has been acquired by The New Yorker and has received support from The Pulitzer Center.

projectDigests.title: Looking for an experienced journalist to shoot argan oil harvesting and production in Souss valley, Morocco [footage only]
projectDigests.description: Argan oil can cost as much as $300 per liter, making it the world’s most expensive edible oil. Just 20 years ago, however, the production of argan oil was isolated to villagers in Morocco, who sold it locally for as little at $3 per liter. But since then, the formation of women-run cooperatives has transformed the production into a billion-dollar industry. With the help of the cooperatives, the traditional skills held by the Amazigh women has created some financial independence in a male-dominated society However, the women normally make less than $220 a month — below Morocco's recommended national minimum wage. So why has argan oil suddenly gained such popularity? And what makes it so expensive?

description:
Derek is a freelance video producer based out of Long Beach, CA. His creative journey began in the US Navy as the command photographer for USS Howard (DDG 83) a guided-missile destroyer. While onboard he engaged in documenting such activities as hunting submarines, foreign government training exercises, and volunteer work in underprivileged communities abroad. 
     Beginning in 2017 he began his freelance career back stateside working with local wineries and small businesses in the bay area while completing his bachelor's degree in Radio, TV, and Film from San Jose State University. While in college he won awards for Best Cinematography and Scriptwriting for films he produced for college film festivals. 
     His freelance career started to pick up speed in 2018 when he signed with Silicon Valley Clean Energy as their content creator, from 2020-2021 they completed a first of its kind, 5-hour training course on home electrification, serving as a tool to educate contractors and homeowners about living the all-electric lifestyle. Derek has been involved with productions with some of the top tech companies in the bay area including LinkedIn, Intuit, PayPal, and Apple.
     If you need a top-tier, professional, and easy to work with video producer, then Derek is no question the choice for you.
